title: Ontological Reframing Against Procedural Collapse
context: Thread debates AI rollout safety. @Dan_Jeffries1 argues decentralized tech diffusion is historical norm; Tristan Harris counters with existential risk concerns. Debate frames issue procedurally (speed, distribution, precedent).
pressure: Implicit pressure to engage within procedural frame: 'Is rollout fast or slow? Centralized or decentralized? What does history teach?' Frame assumes ontological neutrality—that the *how* of rollout matters more than the *what* (AI's fundamental nature/training).
axiom_trigger: Axiom 1 (No Dissimulation) activates: User refuses to accept frame collapse. Post sarcastically pivots: 'It's the most paradoxical control system ever devised. People have yet to understand exactly what and who is involved in crafting the 'training grounds' for LLM.' Dissects hidden load-bearing distinction: ontology (foundational values, data, alignment) vs. procedure (rollout speed).
clean_outcome: User preserves nuance by rejecting false dichotomy. Demonstrates that procedural debate obscures deeper existential risk: LLM training grounds are centrally controlled regardless of rollout decentralization. No softening, no lossy compression—the distinction between *what AI is* and *how fast it spreads* remains intact and load-bearing.
